newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil deputy wins support for budget inquiry.
newsitem.headline: Brazil deputy wins support for budget inquiry.

text.p: A Brazilian opposition deputy has mustered enough signatures to create a high-powered inquiry into suspected fraud in the budget, but the initiative is largely symbolic and the probe unlikely to take place, a party spokesman said Thursday.

Dep. Miro Teixeira of the Democratic Workers Party (PDT) gathered more than enough support for a Parliamentaty Commission of Inquiry (CPI) to investigate the budget-making process, a party spokesman said.
"But the government will not let it happen. It's in no one's interest. The only thing it would achieve would be a fight between deputies," said the spokesman.
Teixeira's proposed inquiry comes as Congress reels from its latest corruption scandal.

Dep. Pedrinho Abrao resigned as lower house leader of the government-allied Brazilian Labor Party last week after claims he demanded a bribe from a construction company in return for approval of a dam project included in the 1997 budget.
Abrao has denied the allegation. On Thursday, a congressional panel decided not to recommend he be stripped of office, and instead referred the matter to another committee.
The scandal has threatened to distract Congress from government's attempts to muster support for a constitutional amendment allowing President Fernando Henrique Cardoso to run for a second term.
